Diet.Â Kings eat one another and common folk too. They can restrain themselves from the latter if well-satiated with meat and grain, but if you put two Kings of approximately similar size in the same Kingdom one of them is going to kill and eat the other one. It’s just a law of nature.

Power.Â Besides being at least as big as a house and twice as sturdy, the word of a King is law. They possess the ability to issue Commands, which must be obeyed by those within their Domain and are difficult to resist even for those without.

Kings of appropriately distinct sizes can form hierarchies, which is how the High King rules the petty Kings of the land and why they haven’t all killed and eaten each other yet (they still get up to plenty of it, but less than they would without a High King in place). Obviously, he must consume any that grow large enough to threaten him.Â 

In today’s fallen age this is about as big as Kings can get, but the histories tell of Grand Kings the size of cities. And in ages long past there was held to be an Emperor, the First King, who if he truly lived must have been the size of a mountain range…

Kings of ages past.

Why Are Kings? ðŸ”—

It’s the essential nature of Man. We are, in the most literal sense, monstrous consumers. There isn’t an easy solution. Humanity has a problem, and the problem is Kings; but the individual Kings aren’t the source, they just happen to be at the top of the pile for now. If there wasn’t a High King, everyone would be King, and that would be even worse.

This is probably why elfs hate you.


No Kings, taskmasters.

A Digression On Dwarfs ðŸ”—

If you want to fix Kings, you’ve got to, I don’t know, abolish the entire feudal system, the whole damn thing, and probably create a weapon that will destroy Kung Fu. Industrialize past it. DevelopÂ capitalism, orÂ state capitalism. That’s what the dwarfs did (both/all of the above).Â 

That will, of course, cause other problems, and the dwarfs are here to prove it.Â 

Dwarfs used to be something much like Man, but they industrialized. They evolved beyond having Kings, and the parts of them that would become Kings atrophied and withered away to leave them something somewhat less than Man. That’s why they’re smaller than people.Â 

Half of the dwarfs areÂ **capitalistÂ **and the other half areÂ state capitalist. The two halfs are, of course, at vicious and unending war. Dwarfs don’t consume, they hoardÂ and mise.Â They eat only as much as they need to be productive. When Dwarf Reagan dies he’ll leave behind a stockpile of cave wheat and plump helmets sufficient to feed all the Kings of Man for a day, and whenÂ Dwarf Stalin dies all he will leave behind is a pair of boots and a pickaxe (because hisÂ stockpile belongs to the state).

The capitalistÂ dwarfs sell giant armor and cannon to the Kings for their wars against each other, then laugh about Man’s backward, King-having ways once they are gone, their business concluded.

The communistÂ dwarfs back revolutionaries among the Kingdoms of Man, sending them arms and material and subverting their aims towards bureaucratic power.

I just can’t wait to be King.

How Do I Become King? ðŸ”—

Easy, you eat one. It’s hard not to, once you’ve done the work of killing him: A King-corpse calls to the soul (and stomach) of all true Men. If you eat a King you become a King, no tricks or gotchas. You also become an NPC, but you can make your new character at the level of your old one (that just became a King) plus one.Â Tempting, right?

Of course, if you get yourself into a situation where you’re a King in all but name, it’ll probably happen on its own anyway. Difficult to escape, the Divine Right of Kings (to eat people).

A King on his throne.

What Does It Mean To Be King? ðŸ”—

First of all, they’re huge. Petty Kings are about 12’ tall with 4Â (extra)Â HDÂ and +4 STR. I guess for each tier of King above that, you just double that number, so maybe there are some Old KingsÂ that are 24’ tall with 8(extra)Â HDÂ and +8 STR, and the High KingÂ is 36’ tall with 12(extra)**Â HD**Â and +12 STR. It’s a good thing the Great Kings,Â Emperors, and First KingÂ are all long dead and you don’t have to worry about how big theyÂ must have been.

Second of all, they’re commanding. A King has one Majesty DieÂ for each tier of size he is, which he can roll to boss people around in much the same way a Wizard uses Magic DiceÂ to boss around spells. A King also gets +1 MDÂ for (each of) wearing a crown, wielding a scepter, or sitting on a throneÂ of suitable opulence for his station in the exact same way that a Wizard gets MDÂ for wearing a sufficiently magical Wizard Robe.

Majesty DiceÂ automatically work on anyone the King can be said to rule, and never work on other Kings (even lesser ones). PCs, anarchists,Â the subjects of other Kings, and so onÂ fall somewhere in the middle and get to save. Histories tell of Kings who could commandÂ seas to part, skies to clear, and Men to fall dead on the spot, but that art has been lost or else is being carefully concealed.

When a King eats another King that’s bigger than he is, he absorbs his mass with 100% efficiency. The new King is the size of both Kings added together. When a King eats another King smaller than he is, or anyone who isn’t a King, he digests them and shits out the bones.

Is this post done? Did I forget anything? How do you kill the High King and end feudalism properly, without taking his place? Where do the elfs come in? These are the questions which must be answered, if we are to progress as a people.

item.title: He Who Greets the Sun with a Hymn Does Not Notice the Small Spots (Class: Paladin)
item.description:
The final “base class” for the Mountain, just in timeat least a week and a half too lateÂ for me to run a game. These owe, obviously, a great debt to the masked clericsÂ of G_d.

Three of Wands.

Class: Paladin ðŸ”—

Every paladin has a Revelation; a vision which causes them to break with the dogma of the Church and leads them to the Mountain on a divine mission. Every paladin is a prophet, an apostate, and a heretic, blessed with divine self-righteousness and strength of faith; it is theyÂ who have heard the word of G_d, theyÂ who speak holy truth, and theyÂ who decide what is divine necessity and what is false ceremony.

There’s a big Church back in the Civilized Lands, with complex theology and dogma and all of that nonsense. You’re not connected to it and don’t have to worry about any of that. You may end up with one or two strictures by virtue of your Revelation and Miracles, but that’s it. The things you do are holy by definition; feel free to associate with witches and thiefsÂ and by your presence they shall be redeemed.Â 

Every template of Paladin you have gives you +1 to resisting coercion and withstanding hardship.Â Your second and fourth templates also each give you +1 to-hit.Â My system doesn’t actually have proficiencyÂ so I don’t know why I keep listing them off like it does and I’m not going to anymore.

Skills:Â 1.Â Farming 2.Â Rhetoric**Â 3.**Â Prophecy

Starting Equipment:Â A holy symbol, a short stave,Â practical clothingÂ and a rucksack, a wool blanket, waterskin, 3**Â torches**, 3 iron rations, 50’ of stout hempen rope, a book of hymns and folk songs, and one relicÂ from the list at the end.

AÂ Orisons, First Revelation
BÂ Miracles, +1 MD
CÂ Fury, Second Revelation
DÂ Coronation, +1 MD

A: Orisons
At will, you may do any of the following:

  • Conjure a torch-sized flame into your cupped palm.
  • Consecrate a man-made flame of bonfire size or smaller, causing it to produce no ash nor smoke.
  • Refuse to be burned by any fire of not-specifically-malicious intent.
  • Know the position of the sun, the approximate time and exact date, and which cardinal direction you are facing.

A: Revelation
As a paladin, you have received a revelation; a prophetic vision with more weight and detail to it than the nightmarish dreams suffered by most who are called to the Mountain, shewing them a potential End of the World as well as a means by which it may be averted. Each paladin’s revelation is unique, but four broad themes seem to be present:

  1. **Revelation of the Hearth (Choirs)
    **_Throngs of the faithful gather around great bonfires to repel the assault of infernal forces, vast armies of black glass and iridescent chitin. We’re strongest together; our bonds are our might.
    _Those who have received the revelation of the hearth know that there is nothing greater than what people can achieve in companionship. Their most important duty is to find allies against the darkness.

    Hearth paladins shave and tattoo their heads and bodies, and are sometimes called Choirs. Their primary restrictionÂ is that they may not cause harm to one who has not acted violently in their presence, and their secondary restrictionÂ is that they must not consume the flesh nor eggs of anything with or without a face.

  2. Castigation
    Upon receiving your first revelation, your voiceÂ cannot be ignored, muffled, or muted. When you spend an actionÂ to deliver cursesÂ and invective with appropriate gravity, your target must check morale. If they succeed, they must primarily target you for the remainder of the encounterâ€”failure means they break, flee, etc as normal.

  3. **God Throat
    **Upon receivingÂ your second revelationÂ you gain the service of the angel known as _WORD,Â _so styled because she answers to many names. Her dossier can be found at the end of the list of angelsÂ far below.

  4. Revelation of Gunpowder (Judges)
    _Steel-eyed inquisitors plumb the depths of the world, unearthing great fiends in their lairs and striking them down. Victory can be wonÂ onlyÂ _by discovering and destroying the greatest evils before they can destroy us.
    Those who have received the revelation of gunpowder know that they are soldiers in an unending war. Their most important duty is to slay the enemies of righteousness before they are able to act.

    Gunpowder paladins weave wooden tokens into their hair, wear muted colors, wield hammers and pistols, and are sometimes called Judges or Inquisitors. Their primary restrictionÂ is that they must not turn their back on an opportunity to destroy or prevent evil, and their secondary restrictionÂ is that they may not carryÂ nor wield bladed instruments.

  5. **Bloodhound
    **Upon receiving yourÂ first revelationÂ your senses are finely attuned to signs beyond the purely physical, allowing you to smellÂ the distinctive reek of secrecy. This won’t tell you anything aboutÂ secrets except their existence, but is of great help in discovering traps, secret doors and compartments, people who are trying to hide, et cetera.

  6. Veritas Dei
    Upon receiving yourÂ second revelationÂ your very soul revolts against falsehood, causing you 1 damage for each consciously spoken untruth you utter and allowing you to see liesÂ and instinctively judge the weight of souls.

  7. Revelation of the Torch (Contemplatives)
    A lone hero scales an infinite incline, torch held high, tested mentally, physically, and in spirit. The only one who can be counted on, in the end, is oneself; so each must individually become the best, strongest self possible if we are to survive as a whole.
    Those who have received the revelation of the torch know that relentless self-improvement is the highest virtue. Their most important duty is to better themselves in every fashionâ€”become stronger, healthier, more virtuous, better educated_â€”_and to help others do the same.

    Torch paladins oil their bodies and bare their hands and feet, and are sometimes called Apotheosites, Templar, and Contemplatives. Their primary restrictionÂ is that they must test themselves against the strong and vice versa, and their secondary restrictionÂ is that they may not tell to others what they have not witnessed themselves.

  8. Sacred Martial Arts
    Upon receiving yourÂ first revelationÂ your fists, knees, elbows, forehead, and any other part of your body you could conceivably strike someone with are are lightÂ weapons, and you are a skilled wrestler. When you hit someone with a meleeÂ attack, you can attempt a free combat maneuverÂ against them if you name and describe your action as a special moveÂ (or use one previously named and described that makes sense in context). You can’t use the same special moveÂ twice in the same combat.

  9. **Force Projection
    **Upon receiving yourÂ second revelationÂ you master techniques of hand-to-hand combat far beyond the normal limits of human achievement. Your unarmed melee attacks have aÂ 30’Â reach and you can run on walls, spikes, or water as long as you end your turn on solid footing. Additional secret techniquesÂ may become available to you in your travels.

  10. Revelation of the Mirror (Scriveners)
    Scholars delve deep in libraries and laboratories, their frenetic study essential despite the calamity outside, until finally, finally, the Secret which justifies any consequence is uncovered, the Work complete. Something terrible is Coming, and we’d be foolish indeed to discard any weapon which might be raised against it.
    Those who have received the revelation of the mirror know that all the evils of the world pale in comparison to the great enemy that comes against it, and that the right or wrong of a sword or rifle lie in the hands that wield it. Their most important duty is to seek out power and knowledge that is lost, disdained, forgotten or forbidden.

    Mirrored paladins cover their facesâ€”with blank-featured or silvered masks when possible, or simple cloth when notâ€”and are sometimes called Lenses, Silverfish, Warminds, and Scriveners. TheirÂ ****primaryÂ restrictionÂ is that they may not consciously allow knowledge to be lost, and their secondary restrictionÂ is that they must share knowledge with any who, in their estimation, should make use of it.

  11. Holy Seals
    Upon receiving yourÂ first revelation, each time you command an angelÂ you may cause up to [templates]Â blessed seals in your possession to spontaneously combust: For each that does, you may addÂ or replaceÂ one MD. You can produce new sealsÂ out ofÂ 10 spÂ in wax, art supplies, and precious metals, at a rate of one per day as a part of your normal rest, and they each take upÂ 1/3Â of a slot.

    You also gain the ability to perceive and communicate with the spirit world slightly earlier than your fellows, and the services of one angelÂ rolled on the list from the end with 1d6Â rather than 1d12.

  12. Coronal Mass Ejection
    Upon receiving yourÂ second revelationÂ you are able to resurrect a technique from the holy books long thought apocryphal: The ability to project an exploding laser beam directly out of your forehead at one billion miles per hour. Once per combat round, you may deal 1d6Â holy fire damage to anything you can see.

Breaking yourÂ secondary restrictionÂ causes an immediate mishap. Breaking yourÂ primary restrictionÂ causes an immediate doom.

B: Miracles
The world of spiritsÂ and spellsÂ reveals itself to you, and you gain the service of an angelÂ (roll 1d12) whom you are able to command through the use of Miracle DiceÂ in exactly the same way someone else might cast a spell with Magic Dice.Â 

The saintsÂ of the Church are numerous, and each day of the year is the feast day of one or more, with collisions being the source of fierce dogmatic arguments. Your MDÂ are replenished at dawnÂ at a rate of 1 MDÂ per each of the following saintly attributes you are able to declareâ€”up to your maximum MDâ€”regardless of whether you restedÂ or not:

  • Name and/or title
  • Portfolio
  • Saintly deeds
  • Method of martyrdom
  • Ritual observances

For example you might declare, “Today is the day of Giuseppe the Maligned, patron saint of psychiatry and comedy, who restored the grand mural of the Holy City, and was cast from a high cliff, and on whose day we must turn every handshake into an arm-wrestle,” and have declared all five attributes, and regain up to 5 MDÂ if you somehow have that many which should be impossible.

Upon gaining templateÂ D, you receive the services of a second angelÂ of your choice.

C: Fury
When engaged in melee combat, you may make one extra attack each round for free. The extra attack doesn’t, technically, have to be a melee one.

D: Coronation
You develop a blessed halo, the surest sign of your divine significance. This takes the form of either a diffuse radiance projected around your body or a hard-edged circlet of light hovering over your head. Regardless of its form, it casts light as a torchÂ and protects you from harm, granting +1 AC. It is also very impressive.

**Angels

As aÂ spellcaster, you are able to perceive and communicate with the spirits known commonly asÂ spells. As aÂ paladin, those available toÂ youÂ to command (by means of yourÂ MD) are termed angels, the handmaidens of G_d.

OtherÂ spellsÂ may exist, and you may be able to bribe, coerce, or otherwise convince them to join you. By the same token, experienced paladins and such met in the wild may travel withÂ spellsÂ outside this list.

This is probably sufficient to melt through at least [sum]Â inches of stone or steel, set flammable objects on fire, fuse sand into brittle glass, and so on, and you may reroll all invested MDÂ as damage dice when open-palm slapping someone with them. item.title: Do You Not Realize from What I Say to You Who I Am? (Class: False Witch)
item.description:
A continuation of the Work of preparing PC classes for theÂ Mountain. These in particular are archetypes for my Ultimate ThiefÂ and Fighter.

False Witches. They’re called Witches because they use magic. They’re called False because they aren’t actually magical at all themselves. They are, basically, specialists or thieves or rogues or what have you. Scientists. People who have figured out how to manipulate the world in specific ways, without ever performing something that we’d call magic directly.

They’re a lot easier to run out of town or burn at the stake, etc, than real witches are.

Five of Swords.

Archetype: Sword Witch ðŸ”—

_The sword is the ultimate toolâ€”you can hunt with them, eat with them, use them to start a fire or cut down a tree, and theyâ€™re the primary symbol of skill at arms across the world.Â _

This is aÂ ThiefÂ archetype, properly speaking, but I suppose I can’t really stop you from jamming it on something else.

Starting Equipment:Â A MAGIC SWORD, a normal sword,**Â dark clothing**, a waterskinÂ and 3 days trail rations, a bullseye lanternÂ and flintÂ andÂ oil, soft boots, and a cloak.Â 

Benefit:Â You can carry any number of swordsÂ tied into a bundle in the space of the largest single one you possess, and draw blades from it unerringly without spending an action. You can identify all properties of a blade by fucking around with it for an hour. If you didn’t speak swordsongÂ already, you do now.

Drawback:Â Your opportunismÂ only works on sword attacks. Sword-wielders will be naturally jealous of you.

1d12 StartingÂ Magic Swords (or 1d8 if you’re Small) ðŸ”—

  1. THERE I CARRIED, name engraved on guard. He is a +0 light baselard (1d6) of phosphoric steel, with oxhide-bound hilt, catseye pommel, and double guard. Smells very pleasant.
  2. GONE TOO FAR, sings name when drawn. He is a +0 medium langmesser (1d8) of silvered bone, with horsehide-bound hilt and double blade. Can sever and reattach hands without causing damage. The formerly handed retain control over them while severed.
  3. CANNIBAL MEAT EATER, name engraved on blade. They are a +0 medium shamshir (1d8) of leaden copper, wolfshead pommel, and square guard. Devours sharpness of other blades when pressed against them.

  5. SOME ASSEMBLY REQUIRED, name engraved in fuller. She is aÂ +0 mediumÂ tulwar (1d8) of arsenical bronze, with ring pommel and small spinels in guard. Those slain by the blade will grant haruspecious insight through examination of their entrails.

Archetype: Bottle Witch ðŸ”—

The drunk who waves his bottle, saying, itâ€™s mine, I bought it with the money from my wages (paid by private or State institutions), while he is a victim of the Capital form, is also a usufructuary traitor to the health of the species. And so is the idiot who smokes cigarettes! Such â€œpropertyâ€ will be eliminated from the higher organization of society.

This, also, is intended as aÂ ThiefÂ archetype.

Starting Equipment:Â A ghost in ghost-bottle, an empty ghost-bottle, priming reagents for ghost-bottles, a shovel, a **prybar,**dark clothing, aÂ waterskinÂ andÂ 3 days trail rations,Â aÂ bullseye lanternÂ andÂ flintÂ andÂ oil,Â soft boots, and aÂ cloak.Â 

Benefits:Â You can prepareÂ ghost-bottles, and use themÂ with less risk than anyone else.

Drawbacks:Â Those who care about the final fate of their souls will be naturally wary of you.

Ghost-Bottles ðŸ”—

Priming a ghost-bottleÂ for use requires an empty ghost-bottleÂ and one hour of focused work with access to open flame and simple reagents (lead, antimony, rock salt, water, bitter nightshade, and a bit of blood).

Ghost-bottles take upÂ 1/3Â inventory slot each. The priming reagents take upÂ 1Â slot in total.

Once primed, a ghost-bottleÂ may be used to capture dying souls, ghosts, demons, spells, elementals, or angels if opened toward them at exactly the right moment. For most people this would take some combination of a DEXÂ check (to get the timing right) and an opposedÂ CHAÂ roll (to overpower the ghost), but the first isn’t a problem for bottle witches as long as they’re prepared and the second isn’t a problem as long as they’re not trying to catch an emperor or an archdemon etc.

Once captured, a bottle-ghostÂ may be used in one of several ways:

  • You can drink it. This kills the bottle-ghost, heals you, will probably have other effects, and is rightly seen by all intelligent creatures as an incredibly evil act.
  • You can let it go for good. This empties the ghost-bottle, so you can primeÂ it to capture another ghost.
  • You can send it to scout a nearby area. This takes 10 minutes, after which the ghost will return to its bottle with 1d6Â pieces of information. Ghosts are best at sensing spellcasters, powerful magic, and other spiritual beings, and very bad at sensing architecture and mundane itemsâ€”and will return information in approximately this order. This is usually safe, unless something that can both see and affect ghosts is in the area to be scouted.
  • You can send it to haunt a creature. The ghost and its target roll opposed CHAâ€”if the ghost wins, it imposes a penalty equal to itsÂ HDÂ on all actions the target takes. Should the target die while being haunted, the ghost will attempt to possessÂ it (as below)â€”if the ghost fails, it dissipates permanently.
  • You can attempt to have it possess something. The ghost and its target roll opposedÂ CHAâ€”if the ghost wins, itÂ now controls the target’s actions. If the target is of equal HDÂ to the ghost or better, the target may try again each round until successfulâ€”at which point the ghost dissipatesÂ permanently. Ghosts possessing a body are under no obligation to their bottle-witch and may be hostile, particularly if recently captured. Inanimate or unconscious targets don’t get to save.
  • Maybe it can do something else, depending on who it is. These additional abilitiesâ€”active onesâ€”are only usable once per ‘scene’ or so; a ghost needs time to rest.

All of these are technically possible for non-bottle-witches to accomplish, but much riskier and likely to result in the ghost dissipating permanently regardless of outcome.

1d20 StartingÂ Bottle-Ghosts ðŸ”—

  1. Skilled Sailor, 1 HDâ€”Has a little ship in the bottle with him.
  2. Really Good Dog, 1 HDâ€”Eager to please, not very bright.
  3. Optimistic Beheading Victim, 1 HDâ€”Very positive.
  4. A Flat Miner, 1 HDâ€”Passively warns of pitfalls and crush hazards.
  5. Unlucky Thief, 1 HDâ€”Gives 2d6Â pieces of information when scouting.

  7. Really Annoying Bard, 1 HDâ€”CountsÂ as 2 HDÂ for haunting.
  8. Hungry Poacher, 1 HDâ€”Also notes all animals when scouting.
  9. Cheating Gambler, 1 HDâ€”Can rig games of chance in your favor.
  10. Opium Scholar, 1 HDâ€”Spins elaborate false histories. +2 INT.
  11. Obsessed Locksmith, 1 HDâ€”Can pick locks for you.
  12. Paranoid Apprentice, 1 HDâ€”Passively senses the presence or absence of wizards.
  13. Aggressive Goat, 1 HDâ€”CanÂ shoveÂ man-sized or smaller creaturesÂ 5’Â at a time.
  14. Anchorite Scribe, 1 HDâ€”Is literate, can read to you. +3 INT.
  15. Primitive “Botanist”, 1 HDâ€”Knows which mushrooms and berries will make you shit blood.
  16. Mountain Lion, 2 HDâ€”Makes incredibly realistic mountain lion noises.
  17. Old Soldier, 2 HDâ€”Also notes arms and armor when scouting.
  18. Loyal Ox, 2 HDâ€”Can move unattended ox-portable object up toÂ 60’.
  19. Spooky Horse, 2 HDâ€”Can carry you 30’Â in a massive leap.
  20. Ancient Sword Master, 4 HDâ€”Refuses to hauntÂ or scout, it’s beneath her.

Eight of Cups.

Archetype: Mask Witch ðŸ”—

Some students do not realize the true man in a mask

Because they recognize ego-soul.

Ego-soul is the seed of birth and death,

And foolish people call it the true man.

This, also also, is intended as aÂ ThiefÂ archetype.

Starting Equipment:Â A corpse-mask, a regular mask, three very sharpÂ knivesÂ in various sizes, a formidableÂ sewing kit,a bottle of formaldehyde,Â dark clothing, aÂ waterskinÂ andÂ 3 days trail rations,Â aÂ bullseye lanternÂ andÂ flintÂ andÂ oil,Â soft boots, and aÂ cloak.Â 

Benefits:Â You can prepareÂ corpse-masks, and wear them to gain strange powers.

Drawbacks:Â Those who care about the final fate of their bodies will be naturally wary of you.

Corpse-Masks ðŸ”—

Someone who knows how (that’s you) can make a death mask out of someone’s face with the aid of a good sewing kit and a wood or bone frame in, I don’t know, about an hour, maybe longer if they’ve got a significantly different sized head. Someone who knows how (also you) can gain certain powers or abilities from wearing said mask. These two skills do not ordinarily coreside in the same person. That makes you special.

The bare minimum effect for a corpse-mask is +1 to the highest stat of the corpse it was made from, while you wear it. More often, they’ll give you a weird little passive ability instead. Exceptionally powerful corpse-masks may even have someÂ effect when worn by a non-mask-witch.

Masks take up 1/3Â slot each, and the sewing kit is another 1/3. Switching between masks takes at least an action, even if you’ve got them all handy.

1d10 StartingÂ Corpse-Masks ðŸ”—

  1. Assâ€”GainÂ +1 STR.
  2. Dancerâ€”GainÂ +1 DEX.
  3. Giant Ravenâ€”GainÂ +1 INT.
  4. Beautiful Childâ€”GainÂ +1 CHA.
  5. Croneâ€”Gain skillÂ at diviningÂ and botanyÂ andÂ midwifery.
  6. Giant Owlâ€”Can do the spooky head thing, and see just fine in starlight.

Knight of Disks.

Archetype: Gutter Knight ðŸ”—

_The ancient kings secured good government of their kingdoms through learning of honor, of humility, of virtue, and by acting charitably to those lesser than they.Â _It is the duty of every great knight, to find a quest in life, and brave the demons of the age.

This is notÂ a thief archetype. It’s not even really a false witch. Certainly nobody is calling gutter knights witches and running them out of town. Quite the opposite, in fact. This is intended as an archetype ofÂ Ultimate Fighter.Â 

Gutter knights are a part of the noble caste of the civilized world, scions of great houses of the River Kingdoms and Charter Nations. They journey and commit acts of conspicuous heroism as a coming-of-age ritual, before eventually hanging up their cloak and returning to take their place in the gentry; theoretically humbled and made wiser by their experience. In practice few venture far from home, but someâ€”more dedicated or naive than most, or attempting to distinguish themselves from their siblingsâ€”do wind up on the shores of the Mountain.Â 

There is no moth elf nobility, but some individuals have taken up the tradition nonethelessâ€”their blades rusted and crudely made, their armor unpolished, their quilted favor-cloaks bedraggled, tattered and nearly bare, and their actions unbound by the centuries of tradition that weigh heavily on other gutter knights.

Starting Equipment:Â AÂ signet ringandsealing wax, a heavyÂ steel longsword, odachi, or zhanmadao,Â a masterfully crafted**Â plate cuirass****,**an ostentatious formal outfit, a set of well-crafted traveling clothes, a fine tabard, silk pyjamas, your quilted favor-cloakÂ and a single patch-favor, jewelry worth 300 sp, an astrolabe, a sextant, spyglass, compass, and map each in their own carrying case, and no food or water. Moth elf “gutter knights” have regular equipment instead, besides the favor-cloak.

Benefits:Â You can carry and use patch-favors, tokens of magical appreciation for your errantry. Unless you are a moth elf, you may rely on your family nameÂ to secure respect, food, lodging, and knightly questsÂ in any settlement large enough to have a mayor.

Drawbacks:Â You are not permitted to carry any currencyÂ nor possess any items not carried by you personallyÂ with the exception of a mount, saddle, and riding tack. Unless you are a moth elf, you may not strike a surprised, surrendered, or helplessÂ humanoid foe.

Patch-Favors ðŸ”—

A patch-favor is a little scrap of canvas, linen, or burlap, painted or embroidered with a token. They are traditionally granted to gutter knights for the completion of knightly quests, but if there’s nobody around capable or willing of creating one the gutter knight is permitted to make their own to commemorate a particularly noble deed.

Patch-favors take an actionÂ to pull from one’s quilted favor-cloak and slap on something within arm’s reach. They require contact with both the gutter knight and their intended target to activate, so you can’t put them on sticks or arrows and using them on unwilling targets is an**Â attack**Â made against AC 10. Each patch-favor can be used onceÂ per day.

This power allegedly comes from deals struck between noble bloodlines and fey courts in ages long-past, and patch-favors do not function in the hands of anyone but a gutter knight.

1d12 Starting Patch-Favors ðŸ”—

  1. Torchâ€”For rescuing a peasant boy from a cave. Sets something on fire.
  2. Paper Soldierâ€”For defending a library from book-burners. GrapplesÂ with +5 STR.
  3. Mighty Oakâ€”For saving a dryad’s grove from loggers. Makes a very large tree very fast.
  4. Trick Ropeâ€”For rescuing a street performer from the gallows. Creates 50’Â of animate rope that obeys your commands.
  5. Scarfâ€”For seeking out a magical yarn for a tailor. Allows the target to ignore inclement weather for 24 hours.
  6. Windmillâ€”For putting out a village fire. Blows away anything not securely anchored to the ground.
  7. Bathtubâ€”For running a pervert out of a brothel. Cleans target and gives it a delicate scent of flowers.
  8. Bandageâ€”For binding the wounds of a wartime casualty. Heals 2d8Â HP.
  9. Dragon Scaleâ€”For driving a pack of kobold raiders away from a monastery. Renders the target immune to fire for 1 hour.
  10. Roseâ€”For chasing off the unwanted suitor of a handmaiden. Creates a thorned thicket covering five contiguous 10’Â squares.
  11. Lanceâ€”For slaying an ogre. Deals 4d8Â damage.
  12. Conchâ€”For cutting a nymph free of a fishing net. Summons 1d20Â friendly sealions.

item.title: Something Wicked This Way Comes (Class: Witch)
item.description:
Alright, buckle the fuck up, this is a long one. This isn’t a simplified classis, like the Fighter or the Thief. This is a whole-ass Witch.

A real one, in case you were wondering.

Five of Cups.

Class: Witch (True) ðŸ”—

Witches are dark creatures born to followers of the Old Ways who have consorted with spirits, monsters, or beasts. More monster than man, they are an object of both fear and awe. Witches across the old world are regularly abandoned or exiled, so naturally many of them find their way to the Mountain.

There are at least four kinds of witchâ€”categorized by the form which their familiarÂ takesâ€”but all share certain traits and abilities. Most important among these is the ability to perceive, communicate with, and command demonsÂ through the use ofÂ Maleficent Dice, a process that functionsÂ exactly identical to that for casting spellsÂ with Magic Dice. If you’re playing in a system with proficiency,Â you have it in staves, knives, scythes, and sickles. If you’re a gun witch, you’re also proficient with all types of firearm.

Skills:Â 1. Herbalism 2.Â Divining 3.Â Theatrics

Starting Equipment:Â Peasant clothing, a satchel, a skin of water, a skin of wine, a flint fire-striker, 10 candles, 3 rations of jerky, your choice of a golden sickle or jeweled kris (each aÂ lightÂ weapon), one witching toolÂ from the list at the end.Â 

If you’re a gun witch, you also start with 10 witch-bullets and a powderhorn containing 10 doses of witch-powder. They’re actually normal bullets and powder, but you’re a witch. 1 slot each.

AÂ Flawed, Familiar, Black Magic, 1 MD
BÂ Trophy Casting, +1 MD
CÂ Improved Familiar, +1 MD
DÂ Witch’s Curse, +1 MD

**A: FlawedÂ 
**While directly exposed to the object of your supernaturalÂ weakness, you experience extreme pain and revulsion and suffer -2 to all rolls orÂ 1 damage per round as your form visibly rots, burns, or melts away (whichever effects your GMÂ feels are appropriate). You can take measures to protect yourself; for example a weakness to sunlight can be minimized with voluminous clothing and a parasol.

Good weaknesses include but are not limited to:Â 

  1. Sunlight and depictions of the sun
  2. Precious metals
  3. Ferrous metals
  4. Melodies
  5. Your own reflection
  6. Expressions of strong emotion
  7. Dogs, horses, and whales
  8. Running water
  9. Oil
  10. Prepared food and cut stone

A: Familiar
As a witch, you have the ability to separate and externalize a piece of yourselfÂ in the form of a familiar. This takes 10 minutes of concentrationÂ and 1d6 HPÂ each time you do it. If destroyed or separated from you, your familiars melt into a mess of blood and keratin over the next 4 days.

What form your familiar takes determines what sort of witch you are, or perhaps the other way around. You have four options:

  1. Gun Witch
    As a gun witch, your familiars are witch-guns, up toÂ [templates] * 2 firearms. They can be created as any firearm weapon, but require ammunition and powder as normal; deal 1d8Â damage regardless of form; and will not fire when wielded by anyone other than you. You are fluent in a dialect of ArtificeÂ spoken only by firearms.

    At template Cwhen you gainÂ Improved Familiar, your witch-guns deal 2d8Â damage and gain the ability to move and manipulate themselves while remaining within your arms’ reach.Â Gun witches who have attained this power are surrounded in combat by a whirling maelstrom of guns and ammo, plucking them from the air in a dance of death before releasing them, empty, to be reloaded by the cross-currents; while stylish, this is a horrifically inefficient way of reloading a firearm and takes twice as longÂ as normal.

  2. **Bug Witch
    **As a bug witch, your familiars areÂ witch-hives, up toÂ **[templates] * 2 swarms of verminÂ **that move at your command. They can be whatever type or types of bug you want, and you can fit them all inside yourself and/or your clothes if you want, which is just horrid. You are fluent in Skittering, a language common to all arthropods.

    BUGWITCH SWARM STATS (EACH)
    HD    Â 1HP 4 SizeÂ 5’ squareÂ ImmuneÂ non-area-of-effect damage
    SpecialÂ DealsÂ 1d6Â damage per round to everything other than you within its area that is vulnerable to being eaten by bugs (most things), without an attack roll or saveÂ or any of that nonsense. This doesn’t stack because, uh, there’s only enough room for so many bugs to eat something at once.

    At template C when you gain Improved Familiar, your witch-hivesÂ are imbued with preternatural strength, allowing them to carry you (or anything else, though they’ll still be eating it while they do so) up any surface that a bug could climb; or buoy you slowly aloft on thousands of diaphanous wings at a rate of 10’Â per round. They can only do this for a few minutes at mostâ€”you can’t fly overland on bugwings. Unwilling bugluggage may make a STRÂ save to avoid being bugnapped.

  3. Friend Witch
    As a friend witch, your familiar is a witch-tulpa, also known as a friend. Unlike most familiars, this isn’t so much a piece of your soul externalized into a physical form as it is merely separated from the rest of your selfhood and sequestered within. While carrying a friend, you gain their visible traits, restriction, and first boon.

    Having friends is a bit complicated, so there’s a section downbelow (under the spells and mishaps and dooms and such) that details how that works.

    At template Cwhen you gainÂ Improved Familiar,Â you achieve complete (dis)unity with your friends, gaining theÂ second boonÂ of any friendÂ that you carry as well.

  4. Cancer Witch
    As a cancer witch, your familiar is a witch-tumorÂ which (ha, a-ha) quarantines within itself and protects you from the effects of any diseases or other maladies that you contract. You may choose to pass or fail savesÂ against such maladies when you encounter them, and are able to secrete diseased bloodÂ from your palms which causes any who contact it to saveÂ against transmission of any maladies thus contained.

    If you are ever subject to an effect that cures diseases, your witch-tumor dies along with any maladies contained within it and you must create a new one.

    At template Cwhen you gainÂ Improved Familiar, you gain the ability to spray a torrent of diseased bloodÂ from your palms like a really gross firehose. This costs you 1 HPÂ each time you do it, and reaches, I don’t know, at least 30’Â straight up or up toÂ 60’Â in a horizontal arc.

A: Black Magic
You are familiar with two spellsÂ from the list way downbelow. One is the demonÂ known as Evil Eye, and the other is determined by rolling 1d20. Each time you gain another template of Witch, roll once to attract a new spellâ€”if you roll a result you already possess, choose the nextÂ spell above or below it that you don’t already have.

B: Trophy Casting
You have developed methods of enhancing your power and protecting yourself from the hazards of spellcasting, using your blood and trophies with significance to the Old Ways as fuel. You can voluntarily change any number of MD to show a 6 after rolling them, allowing you to avoid chaos or doom, at the cost of consuming a trophyÂ and taking damage equal to the original die resultÂ for each MDÂ to be changed.

Examples of trophies include: snake skeletons, wolf hearts, shark jawbones, and jars of ash from the corpses of sentient creatures that burned to death. Only one trophy may be produced from each corpse, and a corpse must be at least of small size to produce a trophy. A trophy takes up 1/3Â of an inventory slot.

D: Witch’s Curse

When a powerful witch such as yourself pronounces a curse, the universe takes notice. In order for this to work properly you must have been legitimately (in your eyes, and those of the DM) wronged by your victim-to-be, otherwise you can just curse them with Evil EyeÂ like a lesser witch.

In addition, tales of your exploits and magical potency have by now reached the Civilized Lands and caused folk there to Take Notice. Expect an apprentice warlockÂ and 1d6Â furious witch-huntersÂ to arrive on the next shipâ€”if they aren’t here already.

Witch Magic ðŸ”—

As a spellcaster, you are able to perceive and communicate with the spirits known commonly as spells. As a witch, those available to youÂ to command (by means of your MD) are technically termed demons, also known as elementals, though this system of classification is somewhat tautological. Alas.

Other spellsÂ may exist, and you may be able to bribe, coerce, or otherwise convince them to join you. By the same token, experienced witches and such met in the wild may travel with spellsÂ outside this list.

  1. Evil Eye
    A hunched form with a single large eye and pointed ears; or are they horns? Their material appearance varies significantly between instances_â€”plant matter, stone, raw flesh…_
    The first demonÂ any witch becomes familiar (ha, aha) with. He may be ordered to harass a target, tweaking their ears and tying their shoelaces together and generally being a nuisance until given a new order. If it matters, he can exert up to [sum] pounds of force at a time during this duration. Owing to his simple-minded and generally servile nature, he is easy to bribe or goad (using MD) into performing tasks outside his usual repertoireâ€”_nearlyÂ _all of whichÂ he is wildly incompetent at.

  2. Hand
    She is a mass of red ribbons, stretched across every available space. She ‘speaks’ seldom, and softly when she does.
    While you concentrate,Â HandÂ can lift and move objects within a stone’s throw gently at a rate of [dice] * 30’Â per round, or hurl them up to [dice] * 60’Â dealing [sum]Â damage to them and anything they impact with a DEXÂ roll for half. If used to crush, tear, etc, she deals **[sum]Â **damage per round. She cannot affect targets that pass a CHAÂ save (or have one passed by their holder/wielder/wearer/etc), and is limited to targets of approximate mass relative to the number of MDÂ invested in her:

  • 1 MDÂ - a handheld object or small animal
  • 2 MDÂ - a person plus gear
  • 3 MDÂ - a horse or monitor plus rider and saddlebags
  • 4Â MDÂ - a fully laden wagon
  • 5Â MDÂ - a small house plus inhabitants and furniture
  1. Mend
    He is grey-skinned and sullen, wearing something that looks like tradesman’s leathers. Can be roused to enthusiasm by detailed engineering discussions.
    Mend    Â patches holes, welds breaks, and otherwise repairs the touched object instantly, healing up to [sum] + [dice]Â HP to it if it has HP or fixing any amount of damage short of complete destruction if it does not. If an object hasÂ been completely destroyed, MendÂ may still be able to reconstitute it depending on its complexity and the number of MDÂ invested in him:
  • 1Â MD**Â - simple shapes, blocks of material**
  • 2 MDÂ - boats, wagons, bridges, most weapons and armor
  • 3 MDÂ - artworks, siege engines, sailing vessels, complex architecture
  • 4 MDÂ - clockworks, repeating firearms, steam engines
  • 5Â MDÂ - most corpses (though MendÂ cannot restore life), most electrical devices
  1. Shatter
    She is boldly colored and somewhat crudely formed, as if pieced together from scrap clay by an inexpert sculptor. Over-fond of complex plans and mechanisms. Thinks she’s smarter than she is.
    In order to command Shatter,Â her name must be shouted; not merely spoken. She does exactly what her name suggests to any target within shouting distance, and is capable of wreaking an amount of destruction relative to the MDÂ invested in her:
  • 1 MDÂ - A few blows with a hammer (A handheld object, an artwork)
  • 2 MDÂ - Two folks with tools (A door, a chest, a sarcophagus)
  • 3Â MDÂ - A half-dozen tradesfolk with block and tackle (A tunnel, a wooden building, an architectural feature)
  • 4Â MDÂ - A dozen tradesfolk with heavy equipment (A stone building or fortification, a large cavern)

  1. Enlarge
    She is blue-skinned, elephant-headed, enormous. Refuses to believe problems can be solved by any means other than physical force.
    Enlarge    Â doubles the size of the touched target [dice]Â times for up to [sum]Â minutes. If the target is a creature, it gets +2 STRÂ and -2 DEXÂ for each time it is doubled, and anything worn or carried by it likewise increases in size. For each time size is doubled, weight quadruples.

  2. Reduce
    He is red-skinned, bull-headed,Â enormous.Â Refuses to believe problems can be solved by any means other than physical force.
    _ReduceÂ halves the size of the touched targetÂ [dice]Â times for up toÂ [sum]Â minutes. If the target is a creature, it getsÂ -2 STRÂ andÂ +2 DEXÂ for each time it is halved, and anything worn or carried by it likewise decreases in size. For each time size is halved, weight is quartered.

    _

  3. Heal
    _Wears a linen robe, clinical, detached, omits names and pronouns when speaking.Â _Seen it all before, twice.
    Heals the touched target for [sum] + [dice]Â HP. Alternatively, can be directed to solve specific problems depending on the MDÂ invested in her:

  • 1 MD - No alternatives.
  • 2Â MDÂ - Mend broken bones or other long-term wounds.
  • 3Â MDÂ - Cure a malady such as disease or poison.
  • 4Â MDÂ - Reattach recently severed limbs.
  • 5Â MDÂ - Regrow missing limbs or organs.

  1. Inflict
    He is a crying youth with six many-jointed arms. Two cover his face, two hug his body, and two wield straight razors in furious slashing arcs.
    Inflict cuts a given target within a stone’s throw forÂ [sum] + [dice]Â damage. He refuses to be directed against inanimate objects specifically, or ones which don’t appear to bleed or feel pain.

  2. Illusion
    He is long-haired and vain and aristocratic, pouts if formed into something ugly and preens if formed into something beautiful. His aesthetic sensibilities are focused on bright, clashing colors.
    IllusionÂ shapes himself into an object or creature up to [dice] * 5’Â in diameter, which appears completely real and moves however you desire but produces no sound, smell, touch, heat, etc. Shaping IllusionÂ into a detailed copy of an existing object or creature requires either close familiarity or a reference to work from. Creatures inspecting IllusionÂ closely may roll INTÂ to determine his true nature.

  3. Darkness
    He is a three-meter-long grub, black and shiny and dimly transparent. Clumsy, sleeps more than he’s awake.
    Darkness    Â attaches himself to the touched target and radiates a cloud of absolute magical darkness in a [dice] * 10’Â radius. Non-magical sight within or through the radius is completely impossible. He can maintain this effect for up to [sum]Â hours when attached to an inanimate, unattended, or willing target, or [sum]Â rounds if attached to an unwilling one that succeeds a CHAÂ save.

  4. Invisibility
    She is faceless, wearing a dark business suit. She chatters with the neurotic, anxious edge of an inferiority complex, especially when performing a task.
    InvisibilityÂ submerges the target partway into the ethereal plane for up to [dice] * [sum]Â minutes, rendering them completely invisible to normal sight and able to see other invisible creatures and objects. If cast with 4 MD, she hides the target from supernatural vision of non-invisible creatures as well.

  5. Scrying
    It has a boxy, geometrically shaped head and a large, hooded eye. Below the neck, it disappears into a mess of black-feathered wings and a single, large crow’s foot.
    Scrying    Â will allow you to perceive through its eye at will, and can be directed to seek out any target that you know the name of and could identify in a lineup of similar targets regardless of line-of-sight or range, which it will watch for up to [dice] *Â [sum] hours.If it matters, it flies about as fast as a commercial airliner. For each MDÂ invested in it beyond the first, you may have it perform one additional task from this list:

  • Relay sound to you.
  • Relay touch, taste, and smell to you.
  • Allow you to speak through it.
  • Alert you under specific conditions even if you’re not paying attention (or sleeping).

  1. Open
    He wears a jumpsuit or coverall, and has four many-jointed arms tipped with jagged steel spines. He is a creep, a voyeur, a kleptomaniac, and argues vociferously for you to fulfill his desires.
    Opens    Â a target within a stone’s throw. Doors are flung wide, shackles bent open, belts come undone.Â The occupants of armor, clothing, mecha, etc. are expelled. If the target is secured, attended, or sapient, OpenÂ is [dice] levelÂ with +[best] STR, andÂ skilledÂ at opening things.Â 

  2. Hold
    She is a sinister figure in white, blindfolded, bound in chains and one of those funny jackets that won’t let you check your wristwatch. She speaks in a piercing, imperious voice.
    Closes and locks (if applicable; doors slam shut, drawbridges slam up, half-drawn swords slam back in their scabbards) a target within a stone’s throw, then HoldsÂ it in place for up to [sum]Â rounds. If the target is secured, attended, or sapient, HoldÂ isÂ [dice] levelÂ withÂ +[best] STR,Â andÂ skilledÂ at wrestling.

  3. Terror
    He is an emaciated figure, contorted into a fetal position with wild eyes and every muscle tensed. He is terrified of everything, forÂ absolutelyÂ blisteringly incoherent and conspiratorial reasons. If asked to elaborate on a given phobia, he has a 1-in-6Â chance of being (in some small part) correct in his fears.
    Emanates a burst of psychic Terror, causing up to [sum]Â targets of [dice] HDÂ or less to roll CHAÂ or flee your presence for [sum] rounds. If unable to flee, targets that fail their saves cower unresponsively for the duration. Targets that succeed their saves or remain in your presence beyond his duration are shaken, and suffer a -2Â penalty to everything until they are able to escape you and take a minute to calm down.

  4. Sleep
    He is a twitching, aberrant wreck, paranoid shivers and sharp edges cast in polished steel and white glass. He abhors violence and will wake his targets by shrieking if you plot to execute them.
    Causes up to [sum]Â targets of [dice] HDÂ or less to roll CHAÂ or fall into a deep, coma-like sleep for [sum]Â hours, from which they can only be awoken by vigorous slapping/shaking (which takes an action from someone nearby) or damage, and during which they do not require any food or water. Surprised targets automatically fail their saves, and if cast on a single target with more than one MDÂ his effects are permanent until awakened.

  5. Fog
    He is a pile of cyan-stained rags and linens that only vaguely resembles a humanoid form. A diffuse, pale glow emanates from where his face would be.
    A huge quantity of blackÂ FogÂ pours forth from your mouth and nose, spreading to cover a [dice] * 30’Â radius for up to [sum]Â hours, or [dice] minutes in bright sunlight or strong wind. The density and effects of the fogÂ vary with the number of MDÂ invested in him:

  • 1 MDÂ - The fogÂ is sufficient to obscure details (faces, etc) and apply disadvantageÂ to ranged attacks made through it.

  • 2 MDÂ - The fogÂ is sufficient to obscure objects more than 5’Â away in their entirety.

  • 3 MDÂ - The fogis thick enough to conceal an outstretched hand, and completely opaque to supernatural vision.

  • 4 MDÂ - The fogdeals [best]Â damage to creatures other than you with every breath, and they must roll STRÂ each round or be struck permanently blind if it contacts their eyes directly. When commanded with this number of MD, FogÂ instead answers to the name Cloudkill.

  1. Animate Dead
    She is an old woman, black-shrouded and mourning. Her voice carries the weight of centuries, and she teases at ancient secrets.
    Animates    Â a touched corpse of **[dice] * 2Â **HDÂ or fewer, raising it as undead. If cast with 2 or less MDÂ the undead raised are unintelligent and will serve you unquestioningly. If cast with 3 or more MD the undead raised are intelligent, created free, and may roll CHAÂ to resist being brought back into the world if they desire. The specific type of undead raised depends on the number of MDÂ invested in her, and the ritual preparations undergone as a part of the casting:

  • 1 MDÂ - Skeleton. Requires black gemstones worth at least 25 sp, which are placed in the eye sockets of the corpse. Removing the flesh of a corpse that is not already skeletonized takes at least one hour of solid work.

  • 2 MDÂ - Zombie. Requires embalming and preservative agents worth at least 50 sp and one hour to properly apply them, or a corpse which has already been preserved through similar methods. Alternately, zombies can be created with no preparation or materials from a fresh corpse, but will be paralyzed by rigor mortis within [sum]Â hours.

  • 3 MDÂ - Ghoul.Â Requires a piece of dead flesh and gnawed bone both from the corpse of a sapient creature, a pot of grave earth, a fragment of crypt or tombstone, and ten minutes to force all of the above down the target’s throat and into its stomach.

  • 4 MDÂ - Revenant.Â Requires black gemstones worth at least 1,000 sp, the bottled soul of a sapient creature, and one minute to lure the target’s soul back to their body using the above as sacrifices.

  • 5 MDÂ - Haunting. Requires an item of the target’s that had great personal value to them when they were alive, and six hours to carry out the necessary rituals to summon and re-bind them to their corpse.

  • 6 MD - Lich.Â Requires uniquely powerful reagents that are definitelyÂ not for sale, and twenty four hours to conduct an elaborate ritual extracting and processing the target’s soul. Animate DeadÂ resents answering to this name, and protests its inaccuracy.

  1. Abjure
    He is a small child formed from blue-tinged iron, nervous and fretting with bracelets. He is lonely, friendly, and craves the company of other demons.
    Abjures    Â magical effects, elementals, devils, other spells, the animating spirits of undead or constructs, curses, &c back to wherever they came from.Â He reduces his target’s [dice]Â and [sum]Â each by his own, completely banishing them if either is reduced to 0; useÂ HPÂ andÂ HDÂ in their place if it’s a target that doesn’t have those values. If commanded as aÂ readied action,Â AbjureÂ can affect othersÂ spellsÂ as they’re cast and before they take effect.Â 

  2. Summon
    She is a devilress clad in black businesswear, her proportions slightly off when viewed from the corner of your eye. Her fingers taper to red-stained razor points, and her ever-so-slightly-too-wide grin hides a forest of needlelike teeth. She is quick to inform about the dangers of commanding her, and has release forms and waivers to be signed if you do.
    Summons    Â a devil of [dice] HDÂ and [sum] HPÂ for [sum] rounds. The devil is not in any way compelled to do your bidding unless you know its true name, in which case it is unable to harm you and you may dismiss it at will. Commanding SummonÂ with more preparation (and signing more of her contracts and forms) allows a longer duration and more control over the devil to be summoned:

  • With one round of preparation (a hasty signature, a quick sigil on the ground) the summoning persists for [sum]Â minutes and you may make one opposed CHAÂ roll to banish the devil per round (for example, if it’s trying to kill you).
  • With one hour of preparation (a lengthy perusal of contracts, a well-formed summoning circle) the summoning persists for [sum]Â hours and the devil is unable to leave the summoning circle until you allow it (traditionally, after it’s agreed not to kill you).

Witching Mishaps ðŸ”—

  1. You contractÂ Snoos, a sort of exposure-induced allergy to magical irradiation which causes any further magical effects toÂ stunÂ you into a watery-eyed sneezing fit forÂ 1 roundÂ each. In addition, your skin gives off a faint blue glow until next dawn.
  2. Your veins turn jet black beneath your skin, stiff and painful. You gain no benefit (aside from your blood returning to normal) the next time you rest, and take 1 damageÂ per minute exposed to **sunlightÂ **until you do.
  3. Shards of black glass explode into being around you, pelting everything within 20’Â (including you) for [sum]Â damage, DEXÂ half. Until the next dawn, any wounds you directly inflict on others are mirrored onto your own flesh.
  4. A torrent of winged insects issues from your mouth for [dice]Â rounds, preventing you from doing anything other than stagger around. Anyone within 20’Â must roll CHAÂ or be likewise incapacitated as they flail and swat at the choking swarm.
  5. Your mouth seals itself into a smooth expanse, preventing you from speaking or casting spells forÂ [sum]Â minutes. Stubby mushrooms sprout from all inanimate surfaces in a [dice] * 5’Â radius ring.
  6. Up to [sum]Â nearby corpses rise from the grave and attack you with single-minded intensity, moaning and whispering your name. Plants within aÂ **[dice] * 5’Â **radius wither away and will never grow there again.

Witching Dooms ðŸ”—

Witch (ha, aha) doomÂ do you get? I guess it depends.

Doom of Fish ðŸ”—

  1. Your eyes grow huge and milky, your flesh grey and slick. You can see in the dark.

  2. Your skin hardens to glimmering scales, webs grow between your extremities and your body. +4 AC; double speed in the water, half speed on land.

  3. Your lungs reshape and extrude themselves onto the surface of your skin as gills, and your limbs wither away into sleek-spined fins. You’re a fish now, can’t speak any language other than Hadeal, and drown in open air.

The Doom of Fish can be escaped by capturing the teeth of a sea monsterÂ and burying them in dry land.

Doom of Blood ðŸ”—

  1. Blood crusts slowly around your eyes, nostrils, other orifices. You heal 1 HPÂ per pint of blood you drink.
  2. Your wounds no longer close, and blood beads slowly through your skin. You no longer heal naturally from food or rest.
  3. Your skin sloughs off entirely, and a torrent of blood issues perpetually from any uncovered openings in your body. You can’t speak any language other than Serumic, and lose 1 HPÂ per hour.

The Doom of Blood can be escaped by removing all of your bloodâ€”which becomes progressively more difficult as you advance in this Doom, since it gives you more blood or you’d bleed out even faster than it already makes you.

Doom of Ashes ðŸ”—

  1. Your flesh turns black; your blood thick, syrupy, and magnetic. No wound can kill you, though you still risk deathâ€”and dismembermentâ€”by other means.
  2. Your entire body aches, and your eyes are as black as void. Absolute darkness is daylight to you, but even dim light blinds. Any spells you cast that would create lightâ€”even incidentalâ€”create magical darkness instead.
  3. You fade into a charred and insubstantial shadow, rendering you unable to interact with physical objects or speak any language other than Ember. BrightÂ illumination destroys any part of you that it touches.

The Doom of Ashes can be escaped by giving up an archdemonÂ as a burnt offering, in a ritual presided over by a priest of appropriate power.

Doom of Bones ðŸ”—

  1. Bones rattle angrily about and against each other in your presence, causing you and anything adjacent to you that possesses bones to sufferÂ disadvantageÂ on any tasks requiring dexterity or quiet.
  2. Corpses which possess skeletonsÂ animateÂ in your presence and attack you, and even loose bones gain some level of locomotion and will do their best to harm you.
  3. Your own bones rebel against you, escaping your flesh as an animate skeleton and rendering you unableÂ to speak or understand ClatterÂ if you could before, orâ€”perhaps more importantlyâ€”move in anything approaching a useful fashion. On the upside, I guess you don’t personally suffer from your first Doom anymore.

The Doom of Bones can be escaped by replacing your (traitorous, scheming) skeleton with bones cut from a suitably impressive snake. Some crushing and sinteringÂ may be necessary.

Witch-Tulpas (also known as Friends) ðŸ”—

Summoning a friendÂ works the same way as it does with other familiars (10 minutes, 1d6 HP, et al) but once summoned they are carriedÂ within your soul, rather than physically. If you break a breakableÂ restrictionÂ of the friend you are carrying, you immediately stop carrying that **friendÂ **and take 1d6 damageÂ due to psychic shock.

Each time you gain a template of friend witchâ€”including the firstâ€”roll once on the list below to determine which friend you are able to summon. If you eat the heartÂ of another friend witch, you gain the ability to summon any friend they were carryingÂ at the time of their death.

As with the spell list, this is just a list of those possible to start the game with as a friend witch and more may exist:

  1. Nuul Ux, the Ashen Waste
    Visible:    Â Pallid; emaciated; charred skin flakes away to reveal pink scar tissue.
    First Boon:Â Spoil food and evaporate water with a glance at up to 60’Â range.
    Second Boon:Â Weapons wreathed in smoke and cinders, treat all AC as 10 and deal fire damage.
    Restriction:Â Food and drink turn to ash at a touch, granting no nourishment.

  2. Um-Yanith, the Carrion Feast
    Visible:     Stinking; plagued with lice and fleas; hair falling out in clumps; skin gleams sickly.
    First Boon:Â Can eat and gain nourishment from any dead flesh, immune to effects of rotten meat.
    Second Boon: Gain immunity to one spell or magical ability of any creature you eat, as long as Um-Yanith is carried.
    Restriction:Â Must eat a piece of every corpse you see and have access to.

  3. Um-Sharan, the Chronicle Worm
    Visible:     Corpulent; veins and organs show faintly through translucent skin.
    First Boon: Able to read (not speak) any language, living or dead.
    Second Boon:Â Recover one memory from anything you consume.
    Restriction: Must stop to read any text you encounter in its entirety, and never interrupt a story.

  4. Hexochre, the Conqueror King
    Visible:Â Smoldering embers for eyes; clothing turns to soot-black, cruelly spiked armor.
    First Boon:Â Clothes harden and transform to black steel plate (17 AC)Â while Hexochre is carried.
    Second Boon:Â Body gains mass and scars of a warrior hero, count as having +4 STR.
    Restriction:Â Must respond to insults with immediate violence.

  5. Phoemordia, the Drowned Queen
    Visible:     Blue-black eyes and lips; white skin; yellow sclera; perpetually dripping.
    First Boon: Point to a target within 10’Â of water; ghostly hands (+5 STR) drag them in.
    Second Boon:Â If you die underwater, immediately rise as a ghoul but must carry Phoemordia forever.
    Restriction:Â Halve maximum HP. Followers have a 5%Â chance of desertion per day.

  6. Zoshardan, the Earthen Sword
    Visible:    Â Calloused, grey-brown skin; smell old, like cave dust and wet stone.
    First Boon:Â Create spiked formations from existing stone with a gesture; 3d6 damage, DEXÂ half.
    Second Boon:Â Merge limbs with stone or earth to become immovable; works on walls and ceilings too.
    Restriction: Take 1 damage per round exposed to sunlight or running water.

  7. Vo Fanur, the Elder Dragon
    Visible:    Â Ancient, weathered scales; burning eyes; wispy beard, like cobwebs.
    First Boon:Â Accurately appraise values (of treasure) and ambition (of creatures) with a glance.
    Second Boon:Â Breathe 60’Â cone of poison fire; 6d6Â damage, DEXÂ half, you take 2d6 yourself.
    Restriction:Â Roll CHAÂ per creature encountered or be convinced they plot against you.

  8. Temeri, the Elemental Evil
    Visible:     Colors shift across bodyâ€”deep red, bright orange, yellow-white, green-blue-black.
    First Boon:Â Take 5Â less damage from fish, blood, ashÂ (including natural fire), orÂ boneÂ attacks.
    Second Boon:Â Speak Hadeal, Serumic, Ember, and ClatterÂ with aristocratic airs.
    Restriction:Â Must be touching all four elements (fish, blood, ashes, bones) at all times.

  9. Hulk, the Hulk
    Visible:    Â Muscles swollen and corded like steel cables; skin a quilt of stark white scars.
    First Boon:Â Focused rage grants immunity to mental attacks and fear. +1 STR.
    Second Boon:Â Violent fury allows additional melee attack per round. +1 STR.
    Restriction:Â Mustn’t use ranged weapons or speak except battlecries and taunts.

  10. Gra Yan Eb, the Hand of Doom
    Visible:     Dominant hand drips blood continually.
    First Boon:Â Held weapon drips blood and deals +1Â damage per round of combat (+2Â second round, etc.)
    Second Boon:Â Mark target as an action; one target at a time. Held weapon deals double damage to them.
    Restriction:Â Mustn’tÂ hold weaponsâ€”even two-handed weaponsâ€”or shields in any off-hand.

  11. Dracula, the Impaler
    Visible:    Â Bone-white skin; prominent canine teeth; air of elegance.
    First Boon:Â Gain bite attack for 1d6Â damage; heal self for damage dealt or 1d6Â per pint of blood drank.
    Second Boon:Â Unless beheaded or burned, can’t die and heal 1 HP / hour. Still unconscious below 0 HP.
    Restriction:Â TakeÂ **1Â **damage per second in sunlight or running water. Mustn’tÂ enter homes without invitation.

  12. Cthfanut, the Dark Heart of the Wood
    Visible:    Â Limbs like tree trunks, gnarled like knotted oak; hair like lichen.
    First Boon:Â Thick bark grantsÂ +4 AC. Impossible to understand your identity, even for your party.
    Second Boon:Â Take 5Â less damage from any unnatural source, i.e. manmade fire, sword, knapped stone.
    Restriction:Â Can’t use unnatural tools (sharp rocks or draped furs ok, whittled clubs or sewn hides not).

  13. Mordun, the Moonchild
    Visible:    Â Shed dim moonlight (which counts as real moonlight) from pale, glowing skin.
    First Boon:Â Take no more than 10Â damage from any single event.
    Second Boon: Whenever the DMÂ rolls the maximum result on anyÂ die, they must treat it as a roll of 1.
    Restriction:Â Whenever you roll the maximum result onÂ anyÂ die, treat it as a roll ofÂ 1.

  14. Firmatur, the Mountain Hearth
    Visible:    Â Radiate warmth; eyes flicker like dim, distant campfires.
    First Boon:Â Food you prepare is preternaturally delicious and heals double normal value.
    Second Boon:Â Emotions are calmed within 20’Â of you, aggressive action requires CHAÂ save.
    Restriction:Â Mustn’t make attack rolls.

  15. Karereca, the Tombed Horror
    Visible:    Â Bones visible through flesh and organs; eyes absorb light like holes in reality.
    First Boon:Â Anything with bones that you slay rises immediately as a skeleton, as Raise Dead.
    Second Boon:Â Can control up to [templates] * 4Â undead (four times normal limit).
    Restriction:Â Undead you don’t control attack you on sight. Automatically fail savesÂ vs. disintegration.

  16. Grutulat, the Star Serpent
    Visible:    Â Points of light shine out from body like holes in a paper lantern.
    First Boon:Â Conjure and control lifelike illusion of constellation as long as you concentrate.
    Second Boon:Â Put target unconscious mind into snake-filled coma as long as Grutulat is carried.
    Restriction:Â Must not enter areas of brightÂ illumination.

  17. Aklonhu, the Silent Forest
    Visible:    Â Predatory mien; long and red in tooth and claw.
    First Boon:Â Continually project zone of absolute silence inÂ 5’Â radius.
    Second Boon:Â Your unarmed attacks cause targets to forget all language forÂ 1Â day per point of damage.
    Restrictions:Â Mustn’t communicate beyond simple body language. Shrugs fine, pantomime not.

  18. Tia Tuneb, the Wayfinder
    Visible:    Â Bright light shines between eyes; 30’Â cone of bright illumination and 30’Â of dim beyond that.
    First Boon:Â Always aware of distance and relative direction to peak of the Mountain. It is very high.
    Second Boon:Â Cover unlimited distance in one day of walkingâ€”not swimming, climbing, etc.
    Restrictions:Â Mustn’t ride a mount or vehicle; must travel alone.

  19. Lolu Lar, the Leaping Dark
    Visible:    Â Eerily still when not in motion, then unnaturally fast and twitching. At least four too many eyes.
    First Boon:Â Jump up to 30’Â without a roll, climb anything a spiderÂ could easily as walking.
    Second Boon:Â Sense movement within 60’, no blindnessÂ penalties within that range.
    Restrictions:Â Mustn’t wield firearms, nor cause injury to any of your traveling companions.

  20. Etun, the Stillborn Godsun
    Visible:    Â Soft, deformed figure; oversized head; casts brightÂ illumination with unlimited range.
    First Boon:Â Useful vision; useless vision; misleading vision; or no vision (1d4) each time you rest.
    Second Boon:Â DwarvesÂ andÂ angelsÂ will refuse to harm you, take no damage from consecrated fire.
    Restriction:Â Mustn’t open eyes.

Witching Tools ðŸ”—

  1. Peasant Clothing.Â A useful disguise. No slots when worn.

  2. A nice Satchel.Â Sturdy and utilitarian. This is your inventory.

  3. Skins of WaterÂ and **Wine.Â **The wine is strong, blackberry, and you likely made it yourself. 1 slot each.

  4. Fire-striker.Â A bit of flint, useful for making sparks if you’ve got any iron around. Negligible bulk.

  5. 10 Candles.Â Handmade, tallow. Cast 5’ of bright light and 5’ more of dim, burn for an hour each. 1 slot altogether.

  6. 3 rations of Jerky. Goat, crow, or villagefolk. 1 slot altogether.

  7. Golden Sickle.Â For harvesting herbs, technically, but don’t let that stop you. 1/3 slot.

  8. Jeweled Kris.Â A classic weapon for spooky folk. Intimidating. 1/3 slot.

  9. QuillÂ and 10 sheets of Vellum.Â Useful for taking notes and such. 1/3 slot altogether.

  10. Mortar and Pestle.Â Sort of a “travel cauldron”, a real one’s too big to haul around. 1/3 slot.

  11. Very Large Hat.Â Big enough to hide a small child under. No slots when worn.

  12. High Pointed BootsÂ and Striped Socks.Â Very fashionable. No slots when worn.

  13. Trick Ring.Â Secret compartment. Good for poisonings and such. Negligible bulk.

  14. Collection ofÂ Odd Botanicals.Â Smell bizarre. 5-in-6 chance of containing exactly what you need, diminishing with use. 1/3 slot.

  15. Bottle of Scorpion Whiskey.Â Got a real candied scorpion in it; also quite good whiskey. 1 slot.

  16. “Black” Cat.Â Actually calico, under the mascara. Fairly well-trained, as far as cats go; enough to follow you around, anyway. 1 slot, but won’t let you carry it around much.

  17. Poppet.Â A doll made with your hair. Might confuse very stupidÂ demonsÂ orÂ **angelsÂ **that accost you. 1/3 slot.

  18. Cursed Mirror.Â One side reflects things much smaller than they are, the other much larger. Not actually cursed. 1/3 slot.

  19. Cursed Taxidermy.Â So poorly done as to be unidentifiable. Could be a large cat, mid-sized raccoon, or very small child. Only “cursed” in the twitter meme sense. 2 slots.

  20. Something weird. Roll 1d6:

  21. A magic teaspoon. Dissolves in liquid, extremelyÂ poisonous, not actually magical. Negligible bulk.

  22. A cursed grimoire.Â ScreamsÂ when opened, eats uncareful mice and beetles. 1/3 slot.

  23. An umbrella with a parrot’s-head pommel. Provides off-color commentary and cusses. 1 slot.

  24. Cane with a wolf’s-head pommel. Bites anyone other than you who grasps it. 1 slot.

  25. A solid gold femur. Looks human. 2 slots (heavy).

  26. A magic candle. Does something specific. Roll 1d6Â again:

  27. Casts darkness instead of light.

  28. Hovers above your head when lit.

  29. Never runs out.

  30. Impossible to extinguish, burns underwater or in vacuum.

  31. Burns hot enough to cut steel.

  32. Summons a powerful devil. Does notÂ allow the same sort of control SummonÂ does.

item.title: You Shall Not Steal, nor Deal Falsely, nor Lie to One Another (Class: Thief)
item.description:
A Thief, in the style of my Fighter, I suppose.


Seven of Swords.

Not recognizing anyoneâ€™s right to judge me, I donâ€™t ask for either pardon or indulgence. I donâ€™t go begging to those I hate and hold in contempt. You are the stronger. Dispose of me as you wish; send me to a penal colony or the scaffold. I donâ€™t care! But before going our separate ways, let me tell you one last thing:

**The right to live isnâ€™t begged for, itâ€™s taken.Â **

â€•Â Marius Jacob, Why I Was a Burglar, 1905Â 

Class: Ultimate Thief

Every template of Thief you have gives youÂ +1 to sneaking, stealing, and saves. Your second and fourth templates also each give you +1 to-hit. If you’re playing in a system withÂ proficiency, you have it in lightÂ armor and any type of weapon that can be both wielded in one hand and concealed under a light jacket.

Skills:Â Stealth andÂ see template A.

Starting Equipment:Â A knife, aÂ light weaponÂ of your choice and ammunitionÂ for it if applicable, a thieves tool, dark clothing, a bullseye lanternÂ and oil, soft boots, and a cloak.

A Scraps, Skilled, Stolen Fortunes
BÂ Connected, Hidden Pockets, +1 Skill, +1 FD
CÂ Opportunist, +1 Skill, +1 FD
DÂ Shadow, +1 Skill, +1 FD

A: Scraps
A life spent eating scraps and fleeing from the cops has left you frail and sickly, giving youÂ -1 HPÂ perÂ HD.

A: Skilled
A thief lives or dies by their skills, and by surviving this long you’ve already picked up a much broader repertoire than most adventurersâ€”as well as some special tricks. TwiceÂ upon gaining this template as well as once for each thief template thereafter, gain a skill from the list downbelow. In addition, you gain theÂ special abilityÂ from the list for each skill on it that you have.

A:Â Stolen Fortunes
You have a pool of Fortune Dice, or FD, which are d4s equal to the number of thief templates you have. You can roll any number of these when you roll a d20, and add them to the result. FD that come up a result less than or equal to the number of FD you rolled are expended until you get a good long rest, otherwise they return to your pool.

B:Â Connected
Whatever organization, underworld, community, or creed you belong to is connected to people and places everywhere, and there are signs by which you may recognize and be recognized as a part of the same. When you roll a naturalÂ 7Â on aÂ reactionÂ roll,Â rerollÂ itÂ andÂ the encounter is in some way connected to your background.

B:Â Hidden Pockets
You have [templates]Â extra inventory slots. Items you store in them can’t be found by anyone unless you want them to.

C: Opportunist
When fighting an opponent who can’t pay full attention to youâ€”because they’ve got sand or sun in their eyes, they’re being flanked, you yelled “hey what’s that over there” and they’re an idiot, &câ€”your attacks deal double damage.

D: Shadow
You can vanish in shadows, do loud things (running, fighting, breaking stuff) very quietly, and do quiet things (walking, climbing, pulling a knife, rummaging around in a backpack) in absolute silence.Â 

image stolen (ha, aha) fromÂ artstation

1d20 Thief Skills

  1. Locksmithing
    When you successfully pick a lock, it’s instantaneous. When you fail, it only takes a round.

  2. Jury-rigging
    Improvised or makeshift tools and devices function as well as professionally made ones, in your hands.

  3. Climbing
    You can climb sheer surfaces as if they were merely difficult, even without gear.

  4. Acrobatics
    You can dodge over, around, and effectively throughÂ people and person-scale obstacles as if they weren’t even there, as long as there’s room to do so.

  5. Burglary
    Given ten minutes per hundred square feet, you can pile everything vaguely saleable - including hidden objects, parts of other objects, et cetera - in the middle of a room.

  6. **Appraisal
    **You can determine the value of objects to within one order of magnitude at a glance, and identify them precisely with between one minute and one hour of study depending on scale.

  7. Forgery
    You can forge believable documents, signatures, et cetera without an original to examine, provided you’ve seen one before or have a halfway decent description to work from.

  8. Disguise
    When disguised as someone, you count as them for any magical or metaphysical purposes. If it matters, you can also mimic their iris patterns, fingerprints, blood type, &c.

  9. Forensics
    When examining the scene of an event, you can physicallyÂ see and hearÂ an approximation of how the event played out. This won’t necessarily give you any new information, but it will certainly make clues obvious that might otherwise have been missed.

  10. Anatomy
    When presented with an unaware subject that possesses a comprehensible anatomy, you can place them in whatever state you desire with a nerve pinch/karate chop/stiff-knuckled jab to the pressure points.

  11. Fast-talking
    Potential interlocutors must check moraleÂ to interrupt or disbelieve you as long as you keep talking. You can speak for a full thirty seconds without running out of breath.

  12. Devices
    You can alter or repair devicesÂ effectively even without appropriate tools. When you sabotageÂ a device, you can choose exactly what time or condition under which it will fail and the manner in which it will do so.

  13. Toxicology
    You can determine the nature of a poisoning from symptoms without risk of error, and can formulate a reasonably effectiveÂ poison or antidote from any well-stocked pantry or acre of wilderness.

  14. Linguistics
    Through roguish instinct, you know how to say all of the following in any language that you’ve heard spoken even once:

  15. “I don’t want any trouble”

  16. “How can I getÂ fucked upÂ around here?”

  17. “I have the money, if you have the stuff”

  18. “This is [a] robbery!”

  19. “That’s my wife!”

  20. “COPS!”

  21. Smuggling
    Once per locale, you can have had a connectionÂ smuggle something helpful in for you. The DMÂ gets to decide what exactly it is (which you do not know) and where exactly it’s placed (which you do).

  22. Intimidation
    Your threats are always treated as credible and requiring moraleÂ checks by anything that can understand them. You could bop a dragon on the shin and say “eeeeeehhh nice pile of treasure you got here, be a shame if something happened to it” and they would have to make a morale check. Dragons have very, very high morale scores, but they still have to make the check.

  23. Fencing
    You have a 2-in-6Â chance of finding a buyer for stolen goods in any settlement, a 2-in-6Â chance of knowing if any given buyer is going to rat you out, and a 2-in-6Â chance of disarming your opponent in a flashyÂ prise de ferÂ with the first attack you make in each combat.

  24. Pickpocketing
    When someone tries to wield an item you have a 2-in-6Â chance of having already stolen it, if you’ve been within arm’s reach of them within the last hour and should so desire.

  25. Drinking
    You can identify special properties of beverages accurately by taste. When blackout drunk, you only do cool shit, no embarrassing shit, unless it’s also super cool.

  26. Eavesdropping
    When you listen in on a conversation, the participants are guaranteedÂ to speak about something of interest to you.


This guy is a thief, too.

But Vayra, You Hate Generic Classes ðŸ”—

haha you know what it is

  1. Pirate
    Starting Equipment:A cutlass, a pistolÂ and powder and 10Â balls, a jug of rum, a leatherÂ greatcoat, and all the rest but no dark clothing.
    Benefit:Â You can climb and swing on rigging, ropes, and chandeliers like a monkey, and foes in battle must check moraleÂ when you swash your buckle.
    Drawback:Â Wanted by all courts of the sea and a few of the land. If caught, you will be hung.

  2. **Courtesan
    **Starting Equipment:Three sets of fine clothingÂ (+1 reaction, not armor), three fineÂ stilettos, three grams of fine cocaine, three palettes of fine makeup, three pieces of fine jewelryÂ (worth 100spÂ each), none of the rest of that nonsense.
    Benefit:When you speak to someone who isn’t hostile to you and could conceivably be romantically interested, you can keep them engaged for 1d6 hoursÂ to the exclusion of all else.
    Drawback:You have the romantic interest of 1d3Â powerful, distasteful, and inconvenient suitors.
